name: Purchased goods and services
Emissions calculation methodology: Based on purchases of good and services ( ingredients and packaging) for global operations for. Most data referenced sourcing country information. Life cycle inventory data for ingredients came from the WFLDB v3.4, ecoinvent v3.4, Agrifootprint, and our external carbon measuring partner's internal database. If possible, country-specific data was assigned. If a country-specific dataset was not available, the regional or global average was used.
explanation: Kraft Heinz is continously working on improving the data and calculations for scope 3. We are focused on improving our data breadth and depth. In 2018, we gathered better data for our protein ingredients for 2017 and 2018. This enabled us to update the 2017 protein calculations to reflect the latest data.

name: Capital goods
Emissions calculation methodology: Total EBITDA and CAPEX spending for the company were used as basis to caclualte emissions. Impacts were estimated using the dataset for “Material handling equipment manufacturing” from the 2002 US Input Output Database. USD spent in 2018 were divided by 1.396 to account for inflation between 2002 and 2018, obtained from: https://www.usinflationcalculator.com/

name: Fuel-and-energy-related activities
Emissions calculation methodology: Energy consumption used Scope 1 and 2 calculations was used as basis for calculations. All scope 3 emissions obtained either from carbon footprint partner's database or ecoinvent v3.4 when missing. For electricity, NA was modeled as 100% US; EMEA and APAC were modeled following the shipped production distribution from transportation data, where broader EMEA is modeled based on facilities located in Europe , following the distribution shown in “RER” high voltage electricity from ecoinvent; LATAM was modeled as the simple average from Argentina, Brazil, and México.

name: Upstream transportation and distribution
Emissions calculation methodology: Transportation data for North America region in miles and gallons was used as basis for calcualtions. Truck technology information (EURO 3, EURO 4, EURO5, etc.) was provided per region and sub-region, as well as the percentage distribution of transportation method (truck, train, or sea freight) and the quantities transported. These regional data were used in conjunction with NA data to estimate total gallons consumed per region. Intermodal gallons were distributed equally between truck and rail. Dedicated fleet is assumed to be >32t truck. LCI emissions are from ecoinvent v3.
explanation: Looking to align with the GHG protocol 2018 calculations for this category include all inbound and outbound transportation up to retail outlets.

name: Waste generated in operations
Emissions calculation methodology: Pounds of waste in 2018 sent to Landfill and sent to Recycling for Global Operations, and to Incineration for NA is used as a basis for calculations. Average emission factors per region for landfill, recycling, and incineration were estimated based on category 12 packaging end of life impacts.

name: Business travel
Emissions calculation methodology: Business travel was estimated using 2017 calculations as a proxy based on lack of readily available information for this year and contributing less than 0.1% to the total footprint. An update factor of 1.024 was applied based on “organic” increase in sales. Last year’s estimating methodology was the following: Miles traveled by Air and Rail in all regions globally, number of room-nights spent in hotels, and number of cars and days used for travel in rental cars was provided. Air and Rail miles were converted to person- km and emissions were estimated using ecoinvent v3 datasets for global average transport by aircraft and train. Rental-car days were multiplied by an assumption of 100 miles per day (from http://www.autorentalnews.com/channel/rental-operations/article/story/2010/06/unlimited-miles-or-mileage-caps.aspx) to calculate total miles driven by rental cars. Emissions were estimated using the ecoinvent v3 dataset for transport by passenger car in Europe per mile. Hotel nights were multiplied by a factor of 15.13 kg CO2-eq per hotel night from https://carbonfund.org/how-we- calculate/

name: Employee commuting
Emissions calculation methodology: Calculated based on 38,000 employees (2018 10-K report). It is assumed that each employee takes 2 trips per day and works 261 days per year (https://www.opm.gov/policy-data-oversight/pay-leave/pay-administration/fact- sheets/computing-hourly-rates-of-pay-using-the-2087-hour-divisor/). Per trip, a distance of 14 miles is assumed based on data from the USDOT OmniStat household survey from 2003 (http://www.rita.dot.gov/bts/sites/rita.dot.gov.bts/files/publications/omnistats/volume_ 03_issue_04/html/figure_02.html). Usage of different modes of transportation is estimated based on data from 2009 commuting data from the US Census Bureau (https://www.census.gov/prod/2011pubs/acs-15.pdf). LCI emissions for each mode of transport are from ecoinvent v3.

name: Downstream transportation and distribution
Emissions calculation methodology: These calculations include the trips the consumer takes to retail outlets. Travel was estimated at 10.3km per round-trip, based on based on the National Household Transportation Survey of 2009 trends. For trip to retail the consumer gets one item of each product category, with an approximate weight of 8.5kg. Assuming each trip each consumers buy 20kg of products, 42% of the impact is then assigned to KHC

name: End of life treatment of sold products
Emissions calculation methodology: "The mass of each type of packaging material estimated in Category 1 were used to estimate the amount of packaging waste at the consumer. Ecoinvent v3.4 datasets were used to estimate emission factors for landfill and incineration for each type of packaging. This year, food waste at consumer level was also estimated, using information available from FAO (http://www.fao.org/3/mb060e/mb060e.pdf). To estimate food waste, reported waste percentages for each region and food category at the consumer level were multiplied by their respective region and category consumption of ingredients reported in “Category 1”."
